posts.cooked:
Hello,

Moderators and TC‚Äôs (trust level: Leader) have the ability to delete posts from public view but when you delete a post yourself they‚Äôre still there and can be seen by everyone.

Why is this and can this be changed?
I‚Äôll make an example below.

image2726√ó520 38.5 KB

If you click on the ‚Äúpencil‚Äù you will have the ability to see the old post.

This page shows the default permissions by trust level.

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 20 Apr 22

Trust Level Permissions Reference

Documentation Using Discourse
trust-levels reference

üîñ This reference aims to be a comprehensive list of Discourse features, marked by Trust Level, and including the relevant admin settings which influence them. Trust Level Grid - Defaults TL = Trust Level dependant ‚öô = Can be enabled or...

Reading time: 5 mins üïë Likes: 225 ‚ù§

More users can view edit history than can view deleted posts. What you did in your post above was edit it. What some moderators do is delete.

link_counts.title: Trust Level Permissions Reference - Using Discourse - Discourse Meta

posts.cooked: I disagree that it is an edit as the post is deleted by the author. That is something else.
I just ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù and ‚Äúundeleted‚Äù my own post above. If you click on the orange pencil, you can see the history as though they were any other edit.
I know, but when you ‚Äúdelete‚Äù your post the edit history should be hidden. What if you delete it because there is personal information?

Megan:

What if you delete it because there is personal information?

Moderators can hide edit revisions if that is necessary, but Discourse does not truly delete many things. Even posts that have been ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù by moderators are still visible to moderators and can be undeleted.
That‚Äôs just a soft delete, which is strange too.

I‚Äôve been wondering this, too.

It shouldn‚Äôt even be called ‚Äúdeleting if it‚Äôs gonna sit there visible, because it‚Äôs not ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù
Would be nice if the moderators or admins can change that behaviour.

Looks like there might be something available to administrators

Discourse Meta ‚Äì 17 Nov 21

Introducing permanently delete post functionality

Announcements
new-feature permanently-delete

When a post is deleted in Discourse, we perform a soft-delete. This means that post is still present in the database in case an administrator wants to recover it later. A soft-delete is not sufficient when the deleted post contains sensitive...

link_counts.title: Introducing permanently delete post functionality - Announcements - Discourse Meta

posts.cooked: But that can be given a permission for moderators then?
As far as I can tell only admins can permanently delete. Moderators can not.
Then it would be nice if even users (TL 3) can hide their edit revisions.

Hide edit revisions permission can not be configured.

posts.cooked: I see, thank you @Herohtar. So flagging a post to request a hide of the edits would work?
Yeah, you can flag a post to notify the moderator group and request that revisions be hidden
Thank you, hopefully this will be made easier in the future.
You can always submit feature requests to Discourse
No thanks, I had an account there (never posted) and posted one thing: result account deleted.
